text:
Anyone put google analytics in their docs?
I kind of want to, I think it could lead to some good insights

text: I dunno kinda weird to me. It's not like it's it's turning a profit. I feel like the intention behind doing that would only be to decide to close off more of an OSS project? Maybe I'm cynical.

text:
identifying which pages on the docs people come and look at again and again, seems really useful

Number of people reading docs per week seems like a proxy for number of users

text:
Weird dilemma. Like say you found out some group of users from a competing school/institution were using your tool. Would you be as excited to contribute too it?
I mean - I personally don't care, but everyone has a different constitution. Like I found out some weird small company in texas was using one of my packages. I tried to get a job there and they never even replied! So I was all "hmph see if I add onto that one again". I got over it - but does that make sense?

text: If you have a server anywhere, you might consider self-hosting an OSS analytics service, perhaps a more privacy-centric one (I host <https://plausible.io> for my own website)

text:
While I agree with the sentiment.

Learning to use new analystics software is effort that could be better spent on other things.
google analystics is so pervasive already so one more site is not much.
and people who want privacy know to block it.

text: It will probably be quite a pain though to do this in a GPDR compliant way

elements.text: It will probably be quite a pain though to do this in a GPDR compliant way

text:
I have looked into this before.
Google Analytics under default settings is allowed under GPDR without a cookie notice.
There is a setting in Google Analytics that collects more info which does require a cookie notice, but by default you are all clear.
(IANAL)

elements.text:
I have looked into this before.
Google Analytics under default settings is allowed under GPDR without a cookie notice.
There is a setting in Google Analytics that collects more info which does require a cookie notice, but by default you are all clear.
(IANAL)

text: I think you need a privacy notice though, right? And specify who exactly has access to what data

elements.text: I think you need a privacy notice though, right? And specify who exactly has access to what data

text:
I am going to take back that statement that it is ok under default settings and say “WOW THIS IS UNREASONABLEY UNCLEAR”

Frances regulatory body expressly said it was all clear as “legitimate interest” (legitimate interest does not require concent),
Germany said first party analytics cookies are no problem, but 3rd party (like google analytics) are not).
The ePrivacy Regulation (an appendix to the GDPR) specifically lists them as exempt.
The Court of Justice of the European Union issued a ruling specifically listing them as nonexempt.

elements.text:

The ePrivacy Regulation (an appendix to the GDPR) specifically lists them as exempt.
The Court of Justice of the European Union issued a ruling specifically listing them as nonexempt.

text:
The ePrivacy Regulation is still a proposal, it's not the same as the ePrivacy Directive (which is older than the GDPR).

It's questionable if Google Analytics would give you meaningful results though because people who read docs are usually tech-savy and tend to use adblockers.

text:
Though a possible difference.
Most people read docs on computer (and thus have adblock).
Blogs are often read on the phone.
Phone browsers tend not to have adblock.
I wonder if this explains why the portion of people reading my blog on their phone seems so high. (still only 31%)

text: It will be a lower limit and it's hard to guess just how accurate the numbers are is what I was trying to say. There are some posts out there where people try to measure it. If that's all you need, that's fine but first party analytics or access logs would likely be more accurate

elements.text: It will be a lower limit and it's hard to guess just how accurate the numbers are is what I was trying to say. There are some posts out there where people try to measure it. If that's all you need, that's fine but first party analytics or access logs would likely be more accurate

text: If you use your own domain for the docs, you could also put Cloudflare in front of the GH pages site which will give you some basic analytics

text:
For docs I am almost always only interesting in seeing what pages were viewed.
So something that does allow me to count access would work.

The extra info GA gives is referrer (which I think maybe can be logged on a sever?) which is super interesting for a blog (so can see if posting on HN was worth it), but useless to docs.

and ability to distinguise new from repeat visitors.
Kinda interesting for docs.

text:
ReadTheDocs has support for GA built-in,
and use it on their own docs.
<https://docs.readthedocs.io/en/stable/guides/google-analytics.html>


They *do* have a privacy policy, they do not have a cookie notice
